title: Fix challenge generation in Schnorr proof
body:
## Fixes challenge generation 
The functions in KeyGen and Key Re-Sharing protocols to also take Schnorr commitment as a parameter for computation of the challenge.

---------------------
### ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
1. The Schnorr commitment is taken as a parameter for challenge generation
2. Examples should run with no error


closes #57

title: Fix Schnorr proof
body:
This PR fix an issue in generation of challenge for Schnorr proof. The functions in KeyGen and Key Re-Sharing protocols have been modified to include the Schnorr commitment as a parameter. This changes ensure that the generated challenges are consistent with the requirements of the Schnorr proof.

Alongside the primary fix, this pull request also addresses several minor issues in the sigma protocols.

### Resources
 CG21 eprint: https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/060.pdf
 GG20: https://eprint.iacr.org/2020/540.pdf
 FO97: https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/BFb0052225

### ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
1. Code matches protocols in CG21/GG20/FO97
2. Code should be secure (no memory/run-time leakage)
3. Code is commented well
4. Examples should run with no error

title: C Implementation of CG21
body:
## C Implementation of CG21 (Three-Round Presigning)
This issue addresses implementation of the paper "UC Non-Interactive, Proactive, Threshold ECDSA with Identifiable Aborts (CG21)". As it's advised in CG21, Shamir secret-sharing is used to extend n-out-of-n secret sharing to t-out-of-n.

---------------------
### ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
1. Code matches protocols in CG21/GG20/FO97
1. Code should be secure (no memory/run-time leakage)
2. Code is commented well
3. Examples should run with no error


closes #55

title: C Implementation of CG21
body:
## C Implementation of CG21 (Three-Round Presigning)
This issue addresses implementation of the paper "UC Non-Interactive, Proactive, Threshold ECDSA with Identifiable Aborts (CG21)". As it's advised in CG21, Shamir secret-sharing is used to extend **n-out-of-n** secret sharing to **t-out-of-n**.

### Protocol Details
- **KeyGen:** (t,n) version of the ECDSA Key-Generation protocol (eprint: Fig.5)
- **Key Re-sharing:** (t,n) version of key refreshing (eprint: Fig.6)
- **AUX.Gen:** Paillier and Pedersen parameters generation. We followed Pedersen parameter generation and ZKP from FO97
- **Pre-Sign:** (t,n) version of ECDSA Pre-Signing (eprint: Fig.7)
- **Sign:** ECDSA Signing protocol (eprint: Fig.8)
- **Pi-PRM:** It includes two ZKPs as explained in FO97
- **Pi-Affp/Affg/Enc/Logstar/Fac/Mod:** They match the original protocols in CG21. Check "example_cg21_auxinfo.c" and "example_cg21_presign.c" to see how they are used.

### Guidelines for Example Files

- **example_cg21_keygen.c:** it takes two inputs (t,n) and generates a file "cg21_keygen.csv" when it finishes successfully
- **example_cg21_key_reshare.c:** it takes two inputs (t,n) and also "cg21_keygen.csv" and generates "cg21_reshare.csv"
- **example_cg21_auxinfo.c:** it reads "cg21_reshare.csv", generates Paillier/Pedersen params, and "cg21_aux.csv"
- **example_cg21_presign.c:** it reads "cg21_reshare.csv" and "cg21_aux.csv", then generates "cg21_presign.csv"
- **example_cg21_sign.c:** it reads "cg21_presign.csv" and sign the given message

### Resources
CG21 eprint: https://eprint.iacr.org/2021/060.pdf
GG20: https://eprint.iacr.org/2020/540.pdf
FO97: https://link.springer.com/chapter/10.1007/BFb0052225

### ACCEPTANCE CRITERIA
1. Code matches protocols in CG21/GG20/FO97
1. Code should be secure (no memory/run-time leakage)
2. Code is commented well
3. Examples should run with no error

4. Static analysis should pass
5. Code should be reviewed by two engineers

# Release 1.0.0

Updated code after NCC review

title: Review ncc
body:
Address the findings in the NCC review.

* Add UserID and AdditionalData to Schnorr Proofs, double Schnorr Proofs, and the NIZKP of factoring to make them non-replayable.
* Add bound checks in NIZKP of factoring verification
* Add remark to MTA justifying the random generation
